msItemStruct.note: The O.Lund. inv. no is the number (written directly on the ostracon) given to each ostracon already by prof. Carl Schmidt, Berlin.
O.Lund. inv. no 11 = Tsiparis' publ.no 20 = Knudtzon's publ.no 20
Broken at the bottom; three pieces glued together; reddish brown; verso ribbed, dark, pitched
Two columns on the recto: col.I 16 lines, col.II 17 lines; verso blank

Mentions the names (col.I:) Eudaimon, son of Protas; Onno(phris), son of (Onnophris); Onno(phris), son of Apynchis; Protas, son of Herakle(); Protas, son of Paop(is); Maximus, son of Maxim(us); Ponnis, son of Herak(); Kronion, son of (?) Heron and grandson of (?) Sar(); Eudaimon, son of Kames; Matous (Mates), son of Kroni(on); Aunes, son of Psia(); Kiales, son of N(e)ilos; Harphaesis, son of Tarte(moros); Protas, son of Paminos; Herak(), son of Maximus; (col.II:) Sarapion, son of Orsenou(phis); Ekysis, son of Pro(tas) and grandson of Sar(); Charonas, son of Herak(); Orsenou(phis), son of Phasis; Isidoros, son of Kroni(on); Pos(e)idonios, son of Kmeis; Pteris, son of Deios; Peterm(), son of Amais; Korkas, son of Taphorsa(is); Pesouris, son of Zoil(os); Orsenou(phis) (/Orseos?), son of Phombos; Kalles; Amoules, son of Phombos (/Psommonthes?); Zoilos, son of Pachnoubis; Sabinus, son of Achille(us); Polis, son of Eudaim(on); Pakebis(?)
Katherine Blouin, Toronto, is working with this ostrakon.

origin.origPlace: Tebtunis, Polemonos meris, Arsinoite nome, province of Egypt

provenance.p: According to the introduction to his licentiate dissertation Erik J. Knudtzon had acquired the ostracon collection through prof. Carl Schmidt, antiquities dealer and professor of Coptic studies in Berlin. Carl Schmidt, in his turn, had probably bought them in Cairo. In a letter from October 6th 1931 Schmidt writes from Berlin to Albert Wifstrand in Lund that he has aquired a small collection of 32 ostraca from Thebes, Fayum, letters and receipts, and that he is willing to sell these ostraca for the amount of 250 German marks. In a letter dated September 11th 1934 from Erik Knudtzon in Lund, most likely to professor Schubart in Berlin, we can read that Knudtzon bought the ostraca through Carl Schmidt at the same time, i.e. in 1932, as the university library in Lund bought the papyrus collection (registered in 1933 among acquisitions), also from Carl Schmidt. In 2009 Lund University Library acquired the collection, at that time owned by the Department of Archaeology and Ancient History at the same university.

taxonomy.desc: APIS keywords are controlled locally at the institution level. They are not necessarily consistent.

listBibl.bibl: Ostraca Lundensia (O. Lund.). Ostraka aus der Sammlung des Instituts für Altertumskunde an der Universität zu Lund, herausgegeben und kommentiert von Christos Tsiparis, Lund 1979, doctoral dissertation Ostraca Lundensia, herausgegeben und bearbeitet von Erik J. Knudtzon, Lund 1933 (1946), licentiate dissertation, not printed Gallazzi, C., Bibliotheca orientalis, 39, 1982, c. 577; Nachtergael, G., Sur la provenance de quelques ostraca de la Collection de Lund, Ricerche di egittologia e di antichità copte 6, 2004, p. 91, 93-96 (provenance); BL VIII, 524 (lines col I: 1, 14, 15; col. II: 1, 6, 9, 11, 13, 17); TM 74881
